Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Nicholas Cook is "Spectral and structural properties of sparse random graphs." The host institution for the fellowship is Stanford University, and the sponsoring scientist is Amir Dembo.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposal for this award was to explore the universality phenomenon and its limitations within the context of specific problems in random matrix theory and random graphs. Random matrices have numerous applications to areas ranging from data science to the stability of dynamical systems on large networks; random graphs are important for modeling such networks, and also have important uses in theoretical computer science.

Within the realm of universality, the principal outcomes of the award were
1) proofs of the circular law for the spectrum of two different models of random d-regular directed graphs, in joint work with A. Basak and O. Zeitouni;
2) proofs of deformations of the circular law for random matrix models with structured distributions, which are motivated by applications in theoretical ecology and neuroscience, in joint work with W. Hachem, J. Najim and D. Renfrew.

The project also proposed to study random graphs in the so-called large deviations regime, where the graph contains an excess of small structures such as triangles. A robust approach based on tools from random matrix theory was developed in joint work with A. Dembo; the work has implications for parameter estimation for exponential random graph models, which have been extensively used in the social sciences literature.

An additional outcome of the award that was not listed in the original proposal was an understanding of extreme values for the characteristic polynomial of a random permutation, obtained in joint work with O. Zeitouni. This work uncovered certain non-universal phenomena within random matrix theory, and incorporated tools from large deviations theory as well as number theory.
